issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.html:
@dan77062, I don't think it's just a network error. I was getting that error as well when I started calling the keyboard_teleop class from my code. I believe the issue is that the tfBuffer is not yet populated with a 'world' frame when you are asking it to step. I added the following to the keyboard_teleop.py inside the init(self) method:

# Wait for 'world' to be published
        rospy.loginfo('waiting for world frame to populate tfBuffer...')
        while True:
            try: 
                left_foot_world = self.tfBuffer.lookup_transform(
                    'world', self.LEFT_FOOT_FRAME_NAME, rospy.Time())
                break
            except:
                rospy.sleep(0.5)
        rospy.loginfo('Done initiallizing val controller')

It's hackish, but it puts in a delay until the tfBuffer is populated and stopped the errors.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
It is not just the walk_test, keyboard_teleop has the same issue when you try to walk.  keyboard_teleop works when you move the arms or head, but when you walk, you need the world frame since the coordinates have to be sent in that frame, and it fails because it cannot find a world frame. 

 I always use try..........catch with transforms and do catch the error described here.  The issue is that "world" is not published with tf.    Look at the tree created with

```
#!python

rosrun tf view_frames
```
Not having world available is going to be a big problem for walking because there will be no way to command the foot to a position in the world frame and the control messages we have for walking use that frame.
content.html:
It is not just the walk_test, keyboard_teleop has the same issue when you try to walk. keyboard_teleop works when you move the arms or head, but when you walk, you need the world frame since the coordinates have to be sent in that frame, and it fails because it cannot find a world frame.

I always use try..........catch with transforms and do catch the error described here. The issue is that "world" is not published with tf. Look at the tree created with

rosrun tf view_frames

Not having world available is going to be a big problem for walking because there will be no way to command the foot to a position in the world frame and the control messages we have for walking use that frame.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
@scpeters Trust me, I have gone through all the tf diagnostics tools on this issue.

```
#!c++

rosrun tf tf_echo world world
```
 works but try to connect it to the robot, e.g.,


```
#!c++

rosrun tf  tf_echo world pelvis 
```


works fine on the sim computer and does not on the remote computer:


```
#!c++

Exception thrown:"world" passed to lookupTransform argument target_frame does not exist.
```
content.html:
@scpeters Trust me, I have gone through all the tf diagnostics tools on this issue.

rosrun tf tf_echo world world

works but try to connect it to the robot, e.g.,

rosrun tf  tf_echo world pelvis

works fine on the sim computer and does not on the remote computer:

Exception thrown:"world" passed to lookupTransform argument target_frame does not exist.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
@T_AL sure that could work, but it means our primary nodes for walking will have to be on the sim computer, since those trajectory messages need world frame.  In that scenario, we have to create custom ROS messages to interact with our ROS nodes, which is doable but is a big kludge.  Furthermore, if those nodes have issues, we are going to have to bring them down and back up on the sim computer from the remote computer.
It can be done, but it won't be pretty, and we need to know very soon if that is going to be necessary.
content.html: @T_AL sure that could work, but it means our primary nodes for walking will have to be on the sim computer, since those trajectory messages need world frame. In that scenario, we have to create custom ROS messages to interact with our ROS nodes, which is doable but is a big kludge. Furthermore, if those nodes have issues, we are going to have to bring them down and back up on the sim computer from the remote computer. It can be done, but it won't be pretty, and we need to know very soon if that is going to be necessary.

content.raw:
Remember that the link between the two systems is going to be limited in bandwidth and more importantly will have a huge time delay. Even if you can figure out how to get the tf packets across the wire, they will be very old. We all completed task-2 in less than half the time of the expected time delay.

I do like your setup of having two computers to test this environment. I think that I will have to setup something similar. Any sage advice on the setup.

I am also interested in the answer to Erica's question. Can you confirm that the World frame is OK on the sim computer?

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
It does not make sense that the robot on Mars would not have a world frame. All the values in the data messages are relative to the world frame. If this is not going to be the case, then we would need new data messages to send to the controller. There has been no indication that we are getting new data message types.

This confusion highlights the need to get the AWS Cloud practice SIM as soon as possible. It would be a shame to spend a lot of time developing something based on certain assumptions that turn out to be incorrect.

It does not make sense that the robot on Mars would not have a world frame. All the values in the data messages are relative to the world frame. If this is not going to be the case, then we would need new data messages to send to the controller. There has been no indication that we are getting new data message types.

This confusion highlights the need to get the AWS Cloud practice SIM as soon as possible. It would be a shame to spend a lot of time developing something based on certain assumptions that turn out to be incorrect.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
@NevermoreSRC The challenge requires using ihmc ROS messages.  The walking messages, e.g., FootstepDataRosMessage, SE3TrajectoryPointRosMessage, require world frame.  It is possible to approximate world frame by building odometry and extrapolating, but errors build up and after a few steps, Val will fall as the error becomes big enough to command a step that cannot be made.

Are you getting Val to walk without using world frame?
content.html:
@NevermoreSRC The challenge requires using ihmc ROS messages. The walking messages, e.g., FootstepDataRosMessage, SE3TrajectoryPointRosMessage, require world frame. It is possible to approximate world frame by building odometry and extrapolating, but errors build up and after a few steps, Val will fall as the error becomes big enough to command a step that cannot be made.

Are you getting Val to walk without using world frame?

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
This may be a problem of the `/tf_static` messages not being latched properly, so that new subscribers (such as the ones on another machine) don't receive info about the `world` frame (which is a static transform). The ihmc controller is already publishing a pose estimate of the robot relative to the world, which is the hard part of odometry. The world frame location could usually be a static transform of all zeros, so I don't think it's hard to guess what that frame should be if it isn't provided. I think this is simply a bug in a ROS library.

cc: @tfoote
content.html:
This may be a problem of the /tf_static messages not being latched properly, so that new subscribers (such as the ones on another machine) don't receive info about the world frame (which is a static transform). The ihmc controller is already publishing a pose estimate of the robot relative to the world, which is the hard part of odometry. The world frame location could usually be a static transform of all zeros, so I don't think it's hard to guess what that frame should be if it isn't provided. I think this is simply a bug in a ROS library.

cc: @tfoote

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
Well if the robot pose is relative to the world frame then we can infer the world frame from the pose. This only works as long as the pose is accurately locked to the world frame. This way we could get the transform from the foot to the pelvis then add the pose to get the current position of the foot relative to the world. Then we add whatever delta we want to this value and set that as the world frame position of the next footstep which is what the controller wants. That is a lot of if's.

Is there anyway to get around the requirement that we provide data relative to the world frame?
content.html:
Well if the robot pose is relative to the world frame then we can infer the world frame from the pose. This only works as long as the pose is accurately locked to the world frame. This way we could get the transform from the foot to the pelvis then add the pose to get the current position of the foot relative to the world. Then we add whatever delta we want to this value and set that as the world frame position of the next footstep which is what the controller wants. That is a lot of if's.

Is there anyway to get around the requirement that we provide data relative to the world frame?

content.raw: @scpeters " The ihmc controller is already publishing a pose estimate of the robot relative to the world."  Where is that published?  A tf_static with the fixed world frame is not useful unless there is a transform connecting world to a frame on the robot.  For the local machine, gazebo is doing that, but it is not a part of the ROS tf tree, so it does not go out over the network.

A tf_static with the fixed world frame is not useful unless there is a transform connecting world to a frame on the robot. For the local machine, gazebo is doing that, but it is not a part of the ROS tf tree, so it does not go out over the network.

content.raw: Update: I believe the root of this issue is that the ihmc java node is not communicating properly with other machines. So it's a networking issue, not a tf issue. I'm looking at the settings in the [ihmc networking file](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ihmcrobotics/ihmc_ros_core/0.8.0/ihmc_ros_common/configurations/IHMCNetworkParametersTemplate.ini) for now.
content.html: Update: I believe the root of this issue is that the ihmc java node is not communicating properly with other machines. So it's a networking issue, not a tf issue. I'm looking at the settings in the ihmc networking file for now.

content.raw:
Ok, I just got this working on my machine. I had to set the `ROS_IP` environment variable on the machine that is hosting the simulation to its public IP, and then for good measure set

~~~
export ROS_MASTER_URI=http://${ROS_IP}:11311
~~~
content.html:
Ok, I just got this working on my machine. I had to set the ROS_IP environment variable on the machine that is hosting the simulation to its public IP, and then for good measure set

export ROS_MASTER_URI=http://${ROS_IP}:11311

content.raw: @chapulina We need that estimate working yesterday. Seriously, if that is how we will know world frame, this is way too late in the contest for that to not be available.  With a real robot, you can recover from a bad pose with new sensor updates, but in simulation, if the ihmc controller estimate is off even just a bit, you are going to see Valkyries dropping like flies.  I sure hope someone at OSRF has made Val walk over a network.  I am getting the bad feeling that I was the first one to try it :/

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
@dan77062 I set up `ROS_IP` and `ROS_MASTER_URI` on the "field computer" that I was connecting to the "simulator" and that was enough to to `rostopic list` and echo the ros topics that aren't published by the ihmc java node. I had to take a further step and set `ROS_IP` and `ROS_MASTER_URI` on the simulator with the public IP address of the simulator (not `localhost` or `127.0.0.1`) before starting the simulator. It's confusing because rosjava resolves IP address differently than rospy or roscpp, so some of the topics will fail to send to the other machine, but that's because they are being sent by a rosjava node.

Also, I was able to reproduce the error saying `tf2.LookupException: "world" passed to lookupTransform argument target_frame does not exist.` but it was resolved after fixing the environment variables.
content.html:
@dan77062 I set up ROS_IP and ROS_MASTER_URI on the "field computer" that I was connecting to the "simulator" and that was enough to to rostopic list and echo the ros topics that aren't published by the ihmc java node. I had to take a further step and set ROS_IP and ROS_MASTER_URI on the simulator with the public IP address of the simulator (not localhost or 127.0.0.1) before starting the simulator. It's confusing because rosjava resolves IP address differently than rospy or roscpp, so some of the topics will fail to send to the other machine, but that's because they are being sent by a rosjava node.

Also, I was able to reproduce the error saying tf2.LookupException: "world" passed to lookupTransform argument target_frame does not exist. but it was resolved after fixing the environment variables.

content.raw:
@scpeters OK, that is odd.  Using the setup you describe but with local IP addresses, everything works fine as long as the sim machine and remote machine are on the same local network. Been doing that for a long time.  The issue here is making it work on a cloud computer.

But when I try to duplicate your setup by putting a global IP address as ROS_IP in the sim machine, then different terminals on the sim machine cannot see ROS topics.  Yet you were able to get this to go over a nonlocal network?  That is great news!  Could we try that?  If you provide the IP address of the remote computer, I can try to see the world frame there.
content.html:
@scpeters OK, that is odd. Using the setup you describe but with local IP addresses, everything works fine as long as the sim machine and remote machine are on the same local network. Been doing that for a long time. The issue here is making it work on a cloud computer.

But when I try to duplicate your setup by putting a global IP address as ROS_IP in the sim machine, then different terminals on the sim machine cannot see ROS topics. Yet you were able to get this to go over a nonlocal network? That is great news! Could we try that? If you provide the IP address of the remote computer, I can try to see the world frame there.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
I would like to clarify that this issue is related to network configuration problems and will be resolved for the finals. The tf world frame is not available when the IHMC controller cannot communicate to a remote computer, but we will make sure this works during the finals.

The pose of the robot in the world frame is estimated by the IHMC controller, and this will be available during the finals. I believe the tf world frame is merely the first thing that breaks when you try to control the robot without a misconfigured network. So please don't worry about the tf world frame. This is a network issue.
content.html:
I would like to clarify that this issue is related to network configuration problems and will be resolved for the finals. The tf world frame is not available when the IHMC controller cannot communicate to a remote computer, but we will make sure this works during the finals.

The pose of the robot in the world frame is estimated by the IHMC controller, and this will be available during the finals. I believe the tf world frame is merely the first thing that breaks when you try to control the robot without a misconfigured network. So please don't worry about the tf world frame. This is a network issue.

issue.title: world frame does not go with tf across network

content.raw:
OK, I'm resolving the issue as I have been able to get the world frame via a VPN connection, so it is possible with the right network setup.

It may be worth starting another issue to understand in what form we will see world frame in the actual competition.  Also, that is such a critical component, we need to have clarification very soon.
content.html:
OK, I'm resolving the issue as I have been able to get the world frame via a VPN connection, so it is possible with the right network setup.

It may be worth starting another issue to understand in what form we will see world frame in the actual competition. Also, that is such a critical component, we need to have clarification very soon.
